In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here's a function in Julia that wraps a string by inserting new lines when a maximum text width would be exceeded. You can adjust the `text_width` parameter to set your desired maximum width, with a default value of 10 characters. The function will split the input text into words, and then concatenate them, adding new lines as necessary.

Here's the implementation of `wrap_string`:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, text_width::Int=10)::String
    words = split(text)
    current_line = ""
    wrapped_text = ""

    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 <= text_width
            if isempty(current_line)
                current_line *= word
            else
                current_line *= " " * word
            end
        else
            if isempty(wrapped_text)
                wrapped_text *= current_line
            else
                wrapped_text *= "\n" * current_line
            end
            current_line = word
        end
    end

    if !isempty(current_line)
        if isempty(wrapped_text)
            wrapped_text *= current_line
        else
            wrapped_text *= "\n" * current_line
        end
    end

    return wrapped_text
end

# Example usage:
example_text = "This is an example to demonstrate how the text wrapping function works."
println(wrap_string(example_text, 10))
```

In this example, the `wrap_string` function is provided with a text width of 10 characters. The function will iterate over the words of the given input and add a new line each time concatenating the next word would exceed the set `text_width`.
